moves.1. f4 d5 2. Nf3 e6 3. e3: In this opening, White plays to control the dark central squares.
moves.7... Ngf6 8. Be2 O-O 9. O-O b5 10. a4 b4: Development is complete for both sides. Now the middle game begins.
The position is still even. Some of the wood has come off and it looks like an end game could be upcoming.
moves.17. Qc3 Qf6 18. Qxf6 gxf6 19. Bd4: I have the slightest of advantages because of my better Pawn structure.
moves.19... e5 20. fxe5 Bxe5 21. Bxe5 fxe5: More wood comes off, and now I have a clear flank majority of pawns on the K side.
moves.22. Rxf8+ Rxf8 23. Rf1: I offer to swap the final pieces.
moves.23... Rb8 24. Rb1 c5 25. Rc1: In Rook endings it's important do stay mobile and attack. I now threaten RxP and the slaughter of the Black Q side Pawns.
moves.25... Rc8: Black's Rook is consequently forced into a defensive posture.
moves.26. g4: Time to activate my flank majority.
moves.26... d4 27. Kg2 h6 28. h4: I can now force a passed pawn with P-N5 at any time.
moves.28... Kg7 29. Kg3 Kf6 30. Rf1+ Ke6: A difficult decision. Moving the K to the N file would keep it near the threatened passed P but trap the King on the flank.
moves.31. g5 hxg5 32. hxg5: This Pawn now simply threatens to march to N8, and Black's King is cut off from guard duty by the White Rook.
moves.35... Rf8 36. Rxf8 Kxf8: Now the Pawn will tie down Black's K while my own heads for the Q side to much Pawns.
moves.40... Kf8 41. Kxe5 Kg7 42. Kxe4 Kxg6: Now I have a new passed Pawn -- and my King is in the best possible place, *ahead* of the Pawn.
moves.45... Kf7 46. e5 Ke8 47. Ke6: Black resigns. There is no way to prevent the Pawn from becoming a Queen.
